misconceptions.name: Implemented wrong program (distance instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0–100) and outputs a letter grade based on the specified ranges. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and outputs the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional logic to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade value.
Uses distance formula with Math.sqrt and coordinate differences instead of conditional checks on a grade.
No conditional statements to map numeric ranges to letter grades.
Output describes distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this assignment with a different problem (distance between two points) or reused code from another exercise without adapting it to the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and discard the distance formula code. Start by reading one numeric grade from input, then use if/else-if statements to check which range (90–100, 80–89, etc.) it falls into and print the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using conditionals
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is focused on computing geometric distance and there is no code related to reading a grade or mapping ranges to letter grades, which directly contradicts the assignment description.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output relate to distance between two points, with no reading of a numeric grade or letter-grade mapping logic as required.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of writing the requested Grade Calculator program that requires reading a single numeric grade and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to map it to a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to calculate the distance between two points, or they submitted the incorrect file for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required a Grade Calculator program that reads a single numeric grade and uses conditional statements (if/else structure) to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance using coordinate inputs.
Code lacks all necessary conditional logic required for grading system.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read or adhere to the prompt for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the requirements for Q3 and rewrite the program to implement the grading logic using if/else statements, ensuring you read only one grade input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted source code (DistanceBetweenPoints.java) clearly implements a distance calculation and contains none of the logic required for the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates the distance between two points, including input prompts for coordinates and use of Math.sqrt, demonstrating a complete deviation from the required Grade Calculator task.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has completely misunderstood the assignment. Instead of writing a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a letter grade, the student wrote a program that calculates the distance between two points using the Euclidean distance formula.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program that calculates the distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade value (0-100) and using conditional logic to map it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of performing grade-to-letter conversion
Program uses Math.sqrt() for distance calculation instead of if/else for grade mapping
Output is completely unrelated to the assignment requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either read the wrong assignment question or confused this assignment with a different programming exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The task is to: (1) read ONE numeric grade value, (2) use if/else or switch statements to check which range it falls into, (3) print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is for a completely different problem (distance calculator) than what was assigned (grade calculator). This is unmistakably a misconception or misunderstanding of the assignment.

evidence.note: The program requests four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade as specified in the assignment.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(sumOfSquares);
        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The program calculates and outputs the Euclidean distance, not a letter grade as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (solving the wrong problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that maps a numeric grade (0–100) to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computes the distance between two points for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade according to the given ranges (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60).
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
No conditional logic (if/else) to check grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.).
Output reports the distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different exercises or insufficient attention to the specific input/output requirements of this question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and list the required inputs and outputs. For this assignment, focus on: (1) reading one numeric grade, (2) using if/else-if/else statements to check which range it falls into, and (3) printing the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All of the submitted code implements the distance formula between two points, with no elements related to grades or letter outputs, indicating a complete mismatch with the problem requirements.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinate values and computes the distance, with no reading of a single grade value or printing of a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code calculating the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program. None of the elements related to conditional grading logic or reading a single numeric grade are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied and pasted or submitted code from a different assignment (likely a distance calculation problem) that was not related to Q3 (Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must address the specific requirements of Q3, which involve reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else statements) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four input values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade.
Code performs distance formula calculations instead of conditional grade checks.
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' is irrelevant to the 'Grade Calculator' task.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student failed to implement the correct program logic for Q3, possibly due to submission error, confusion regarding which file to work on, or lack of understanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description for Q3 carefully. Delete the existing distance calculation code and write the logic necessary to read a single integer/double input and use if-else if structures to assign letter grades based on the provided numerical thresholds.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely functional for calculating distance, but completely irrelevant to the assigned task (Grade Calculator). This is a 100% failure to meet the requirements of Q3.

evidence.note: The entire program implements a distance calculator, not the grade calculator required for Q3.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Wrong Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator. This demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment requires writing a distance calculator that reads coordinate pairs and computes Euclidean distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on the specified ranges: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), F (<60).
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a numeric grade
Program uses distance formula (√((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²)) instead of grade range logic
Output is a decimal distance value, not a letter grade
No conditional statements (if/else) for checking grade boundaries
Class is named 'DistanceBetweenPoints', not 'GradeCalculator' or similar
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding or miscommunication about the assignment. Student may have: (1) copied code from a different homework assignment, (2) confused this question with another problem, or (3) failed to read the assignment requirements carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment. Create a new program that: (1) reads ONE numeric grade using Scanner.nextInt() or Scanner.nextDouble(), (2) uses if/else statements to check which range the grade falls into, (3) prints the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) instead of a numeric value.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Perfect confidence - the submitted code is objectively solving a completely different problem. All input/processing/output are for distance calculation, not grade conversion. Zero overlap with assignment requirements.

evidence.note: Program prompts for coordinate pairs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade input
Calculates Euclidean distance using formula √((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²) instead of grade range logic

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Outputs distance value instead of letter grade
Class name indicates distance calculation program, not grade calculator
